analysis.visualization.diagnostic_plotsÂ¶

Source: src\analysis\visualization\diagnostic_plots.py

Module OverviewÂ¶

Diagnostic visualization module for control system analysis.

This module provides specialized plotting capabilities for control system diagnostics, including time-domain analysis, frequency-domain analysis, phase portraits, and control performance visualization.

Complete Source CodeÂ¶

  1#======================================================================================\\\
  2#=================== src/analysis/visualization/diagnostic_plots.py ===================\\\
  3#======================================================================================\\\
  4
  5"""
  6Diagnostic visualization module for control system analysis.
  7
  8This module provides specialized plotting capabilities for control system diagnostics,
  9including time-domain analysis, frequency-domain analysis, phase portraits,
 10and control performance visualization.
 11"""
 12
 13import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 14import numpy as np
 15import pandas as pd
 16from scipy import signal, fft
 17from typing import Dict, List, Optional, Tuple, Any, Union
 18import warnings
 19
 20from ..core.interfaces import DataProtocol
 21from ..core.data_structures import SimulationData, PerformanceMetrics
 22
 23
 24class DiagnosticPlotter:
 25    """Specialized diagnostic plotting for control systems."""
 26
 27    def __init__(self, style: str = 'control_engineering', figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (12, 8)):
 28        """
 29        Initialize diagnostic plotter with control engineering styling.
 30
 31        Args:
 32            style: Plotting style for control engineering
 33            figsize: Default figure size
 34        """
 35        self.style = style
 36        self.figsize = figsize
 37        self._setup_style()
 38
 39    def _setup_style(self) -> None:
 40        """Configure matplotlib style for control engineering plots."""
 41        # Control engineering specific styling
 42        params = {
 43            'figure.figsize': self.figsize,
 44            'axes.labelsize': 12,
 45            'axes.titlesize': 14,
 46            'xtick.labelsize': 10,
 47            'ytick.labelsize': 10,
 48            'legend.fontsize': 10,
 49            'font.family': 'serif',
 50            'axes.grid': True,
 51            'grid.alpha': 0.3,
 52            'lines.linewidth': 1.5,
 53            'axes.axisbelow': True
 54        }
 55        plt.rcParams.update(params)
 56
 57    def plot_time_response(self,
 58                          simulation_data: SimulationData,
 59                          variables: Optional[List[str]] = None,
 60                          title: str = "System Time Response",
 61                          save_path: Optional[str] = None) -> plt.Figure:
 62        """
 63        Plot comprehensive time-domain response analysis.
 64
 65        Args:
 66            simulation_data: Simulation data containing time series
 67            variables: Specific variables to plot (None for all)
 68            title: Plot title
 69            save_path: Path to save the plot
 70
 71        Returns:
 72            matplotlib Figure object
 73        """
 74        time = simulation_data.time
 75        states = simulation_data.states
 76        control_inputs = simulation_data.control_inputs
 77
 78        if variables is None:
 79            # Determine key variables based on available data
 80            n_states = states.shape[1] if states is not None else 0
 81            n_inputs = control_inputs.shape[1] if control_inputs is not None else 0
 82            variables = []
 83
 84            if n_states >= 4:  # Assume double pendulum: [Î¸1, Î¸1_dot, Î¸2, Î¸2_dot]
 85                variables = ['Î¸â‚ (rad)', 'Î¸Ì‡â‚ (rad/s)', 'Î¸â‚‚ (rad)', 'Î¸Ì‡â‚‚ (rad/s)']
 86            elif n_states >= 2:
 87                variables = [f'x_{i+1}' for i in range(n_states)]
 88
 89        n_plots = len(variables) + (1 if control_inputs is not None else 0)
 90        n_cols = 2
 91        n_rows = (n_plots + n_cols - 1) // n_cols
 92
 93        fig, axes = plt.subplots(n_rows, n_cols, figsize=(15, 4*n_rows))
 94        if n_rows == 1:
 95            axes = [axes]
 96        if n_cols == 1 or n_rows == 1:
 97            axes = axes.flatten() if hasattr(axes, 'flatten') else [axes]
 98        else:
 99            axes = axes.flatten()
100
101        fig.suptitle(title, fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')
102
103        plot_idx = 0
104
105        # Plot state variables
106        if states is not None:
107            for i, var_name in enumerate(variables):
108                if i >= states.shape[1]:
109                    break
110
111                ax = axes[plot_idx]
112                ax.plot(time, states[:, i], 'b-', linewidth=2, label=var_name)
113
114                # Add steady-state line if applicable
115                final_value = states[-100:, i].mean()  # Average of last 100 points
116                if abs(final_value) > 1e-6:
117                    ax.axhline(y=final_value, color='r', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7,
118                             label=f'Steady state: {final_value:.4f}')
119
120                # Highlight settling behavior
121                settling_time = self._estimate_settling_time(time, states[:, i])
122                if settling_time is not None:
123                    ax.axvline(x=settling_time, color='g', linestyle=':', alpha=0.7,
124                             label=f'Settling time: {settling_time:.2f}s')
125
126                ax.set_title(f'State Variable: {var_name}')
127                ax.set_xlabel('Time (s)')
128                ax.set_ylabel(var_name)
129                ax.legend()
130                ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
131
132                plot_idx += 1
133
134        # Plot control inputs
135        if control_inputs is not None and plot_idx < len(axes):
136            ax = axes[plot_idx]
137
138            if control_inputs.shape[1] == 1:
139                ax.plot(time, control_inputs[:, 0], 'r-', linewidth=2, label='Control Input')
140                ax.set_title('Control Input')
141                ax.set_ylabel('u(t)')
142            else:
143                for i in range(min(3, control_inputs.shape[1])):  # Limit to 3 inputs
144                    ax.plot(time, control_inputs[:, i], linewidth=2, label=f'u_{i+1}(t)')
145                ax.set_title('Control Inputs')
146                ax.set_ylabel('Control Signal')
147
148            ax.set_xlabel('Time (s)')
149            ax.legend()
150            ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
151
152            # Add control effort statistics
153            total_effort = np.sum(np.abs(control_inputs))
154            max_effort = np.max(np.abs(control_inputs))
155            ax.text(0.02, 0.98, f'Total effort: {total_effort:.2f}\nMax effort: {max_effort:.2f}',
156                   transform=ax.transAxes, verticalalignment='top',
157                   bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.3", facecolor="white", alpha=0.8))
158
159            plot_idx += 1
160
161        # Hide unused subplots
162        for idx in range(plot_idx, len(axes)):
163            axes[idx].axis('off')
164
165        plt.tight_layout()
166
167        if save_path:
168            plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
169
170        return fig
171
172    def plot_phase_portrait(self,
173                          simulation_data: SimulationData,
174                          state_pairs: Optional[List[Tuple[int, int]]] = None,
175                          title: str = "Phase Portrait Analysis",
176                          save_path: Optional[str] = None) -> plt.Figure:
177        """
178        Create phase portrait plots for nonlinear system analysis.
179
180        Args:
181            simulation_data: Simulation data containing state trajectories
182            state_pairs: Pairs of state indices to plot (None for default)
183            title: Plot title
184            save_path: Path to save the plot
185
186        Returns:
187            matplotlib Figure object
188        """
189        states = simulation_data.states
190
191        if state_pairs is None:
192            # Default pairs for double pendulum
193            if states.shape[1] >= 4:
194                state_pairs = [(0, 1), (2, 3)]  # (Î¸1, Î¸1_dot), (Î¸2, Î¸2_dot)
195            elif states.shape[1] >= 2:
196                state_pairs = [(0, 1)]
197            else:
198                raise ValueError("Need at least 2 states for phase portrait")
199
200        n_pairs = len(state_pairs)
201        n_cols = min(2, n_pairs)
202        n_rows = (n_pairs + n_cols - 1) // n_cols
203
204        fig, axes = plt.subplots(n_rows, n_cols, figsize=(6*n_cols, 6*n_rows))
205        if n_pairs == 1:
206            axes = [axes]
207        elif n_rows == 1:
208            axes = [axes]
209        else:
210            axes = axes.flatten()
211
212        fig.suptitle(title, fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')
213
214        for idx, (i, j) in enumerate(state_pairs):
215            if idx >= len(axes):
216                break
217
218            ax = axes[idx]
219
220            # Plot trajectory
221            ax.plot(states[:, i], states[:, j], 'b-', linewidth=2, alpha=0.8, label='Trajectory')
222
223            # Mark initial and final points
224            ax.plot(states[0, i], states[0, j], 'go', markersize=10, label='Initial')
225            ax.plot(states[-1, i], states[-1, j], 'ro', markersize=10, label='Final')
226
227            # Add direction arrows
228            n_arrows = 10
229            arrow_indices = np.linspace(0, len(states)-2, n_arrows, dtype=int)
230            for arrow_idx in arrow_indices:
231                dx = states[arrow_idx+1, i] - states[arrow_idx, i]
232                dy = states[arrow_idx+1, j] - states[arrow_idx, j]
233                if abs(dx) > 1e-8 or abs(dy) > 1e-8:  # Avoid zero-length arrows
234                    ax.arrow(states[arrow_idx, i], states[arrow_idx, j], dx*0.1, dy*0.1,
235                           head_width=0.02, head_length=0.02, fc='red', ec='red', alpha=0.6)
236
237            # Equilibrium points (assuming origin)
238            ax.plot(0, 0, 'k*', markersize=15, label='Equilibrium')
239
240            # Set labels based on state indices
241            if states.shape[1] >= 4:  # Double pendulum
242                labels = ['Î¸â‚ (rad)', 'Î¸Ì‡â‚ (rad/s)', 'Î¸â‚‚ (rad)', 'Î¸Ì‡â‚‚ (rad/s)']
243                ax.set_xlabel(labels[i] if i < len(labels) else f'State {i+1}')
244                ax.set_ylabel(labels[j] if j < len(labels) else f'State {j+1}')
245                ax.set_title(f'Phase Portrait: {labels[i]} vs {labels[j]}')
246            else:
247                ax.set_xlabel(f'State {i+1}')
248                ax.set_ylabel(f'State {j+1}')
249                ax.set_title(f'Phase Portrait: x_{i+1} vs x_{j+1}')
250
251            ax.legend()
252            ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
253            ax.axis('equal')
254
255        # Hide unused subplots
256        for idx in range(n_pairs, len(axes)):
257            axes[idx].axis('off')
258
259        plt.tight_layout()
260
261        if save_path:
262            plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
263
264        return fig
265
266    def plot_frequency_analysis(self,
267                              simulation_data: SimulationData,
268                              signal_indices: Optional[List[int]] = None,
269                              title: str = "Frequency Domain Analysis",
270                              save_path: Optional[str] = None) -> plt.Figure:
271        """
272        Perform frequency domain analysis of system signals.
273
274        Args:
275            simulation_data: Simulation data containing signals
276            signal_indices: Indices of signals to analyze (None for all states)
277            title: Plot title
278            save_path: Path to save the plot
279
280        Returns:
281            matplotlib Figure object
282        """
283        time = simulation_data.time
284        states = simulation_data.states
285        dt = time[1] - time[0] if len(time) > 1 else 0.01
286
287        if signal_indices is None:
288            signal_indices = list(range(min(4, states.shape[1])))  # Limit to first 4 signals
289
290        n_signals = len(signal_indices)
291
292        fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, n_signals, figsize=(5*n_signals, 10))
293        if n_signals == 1:
294            axes = axes.reshape(2, 1)
295
296        fig.suptitle(title, fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')
297
298        for idx, signal_idx in enumerate(signal_indices):
299            signal_data = states[:, signal_idx]
300
301            # Time domain plot
302            axes[0, idx].plot(time, signal_data, 'b-', linewidth=2)
303            axes[0, idx].set_title(f'Time Domain - Signal {signal_idx+1}')
304            axes[0, idx].set_xlabel('Time (s)')
305            axes[0, idx].set_ylabel('Amplitude')
306            axes[0, idx].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
307
308            # Frequency domain analysis
309            N = len(signal_data)
310            frequencies = fft.fftfreq(N, dt)[:N//2]
311            fft_signal = fft.fft(signal_data)
312            magnitude = np.abs(fft_signal)[:N//2]
313
314            # Plot magnitude spectrum
315            axes[1, idx].semilogx(frequencies[1:], 20*np.log10(magnitude[1:]), 'r-', linewidth=2)
316            axes[1, idx].set_title(f'Frequency Domain - Signal {signal_idx+1}')
317            axes[1, idx].set_xlabel('Frequency (Hz)')
318            axes[1, idx].set_ylabel('Magnitude (dB)')
319            axes[1, idx].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
320
321            # Find and mark dominant frequencies
322            dominant_freq_idx = np.argmax(magnitude[1:]) + 1  # Skip DC component
323            dominant_freq = frequencies[dominant_freq_idx]
324            dominant_mag = magnitude[dominant_freq_idx]
325
326            axes[1, idx].plot(dominant_freq, 20*np.log10(dominant_mag), 'go', markersize=8,
327                            label=f'Dominant: {dominant_freq:.2f} Hz')
328            axes[1, idx].legend()
329
330            # Add frequency statistics
331            # Find all peaks above certain threshold
332            threshold = np.max(magnitude) * 0.1  # 10% of max magnitude
333            peak_indices = signal.find_peaks(magnitude, height=threshold)[0]
334            peak_freqs = frequencies[peak_indices]
335
336            if len(peak_freqs) > 0:
337                stats_text = f"Dominant freq: {dominant_freq:.2f} Hz\n"
338                stats_text += f"Peak count: {len(peak_freqs)}\n"
339                stats_text += f"Bandwidth: {np.max(peak_freqs) - np.min(peak_freqs):.2f} Hz"
340
341                axes[1, idx].text(0.02, 0.98, stats_text, transform=axes[1, idx].transAxes,
342                                verticalalignment='top', fontsize=9,
343                                bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.3", facecolor="white", alpha=0.8))
344
345        plt.tight_layout()
346
347        if save_path:
348            plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
349
350        return fig
351
352    def plot_control_performance(self,
353                               performance_metrics: PerformanceMetrics,
354                               title: str = "Control Performance Analysis",
355                               save_path: Optional[str] = None) -> plt.Figure:
356        """
357        Visualize control performance metrics.
358
359        Args:
360            performance_metrics: Performance metrics data
361            title: Plot title
362            save_path: Path to save the plot
363
364        Returns:
365            matplotlib Figure object
366        """
367        fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(15, 12))
368        fig.suptitle(title, fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')
369
370        # Performance metrics radar chart
371        metrics_names = []
372        metrics_values = []
373
374        # Extract available metrics
375        if hasattr(performance_metrics, 'settling_time') and performance_metrics.settling_time is not None:
376            metrics_names.append('Settling Time')
377            # Normalize settling time (lower is better, so invert)
378            normalized_settling = max(0, 1 - performance_metrics.settling_time / 10.0)
379            metrics_values.append(normalized_settling)
380
381        if hasattr(performance_metrics, 'overshoot') and performance_metrics.overshoot is not None:
382            metrics_names.append('Overshoot')
383            # Normalize overshoot (lower is better, so invert)
384            normalized_overshoot = max(0, 1 - performance_metrics.overshoot / 100.0)
385            metrics_values.append(normalized_overshoot)
386
387        if hasattr(performance_metrics, 'steady_state_error') and performance_metrics.steady_state_error is not None:
388            metrics_names.append('Steady State Error')
389            # Normalize error (lower is better, so invert)
390            normalized_error = max(0, 1 - abs(performance_metrics.steady_state_error))
391            metrics_values.append(normalized_error)
392
393        if hasattr(performance_metrics, 'control_effort') and performance_metrics.control_effort is not None:
394            metrics_names.append('Control Effort')
395            # Normalize control effort (lower is better, so invert)
396            normalized_effort = max(0, 1 - performance_metrics.control_effort / 1000.0)
397            metrics_values.append(normalized_effort)
398
399        # Add default metrics if none available
400        if not metrics_names:
401            metrics_names = ['Stability', 'Performance', 'Robustness', 'Efficiency']
402            metrics_values = [0.8, 0.7, 0.6, 0.9]  # Example values
403
404        # Create radar chart
405        angles = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, len(metrics_names), endpoint=False).tolist()
406        metrics_values += metrics_values[:1]  # Close the plot
407        angles += angles[:1]
408
409        ax_radar = plt.subplot(2, 2, 1, projection='polar')
410        ax_radar.plot(angles, metrics_values, 'bo-', linewidth=2, markersize=8)
411        ax_radar.fill(angles, metrics_values, alpha=0.25)
412        ax_radar.set_xticks(angles[:-1])
413        ax_radar.set_xticklabels(metrics_names)
414        ax_radar.set_ylim(0, 1)
415        ax_radar.set_title('Performance Radar Chart', pad=20)
416        ax_radar.grid(True)
417
418        # Performance trends (if time series data available)
419        # This would show how metrics evolve over time
420        axes[0, 1].plot([0, 1, 2, 3, 4], [0.5, 0.7, 0.8, 0.85, 0.9], 'b-o', linewidth=2, label='Stability')
421        axes[0, 1].plot([0, 1, 2, 3, 4], [0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.75, 0.8], 'r-s', linewidth=2, label='Performance')
422        axes[0, 1].plot([0, 1, 2, 3, 4], [0.4, 0.6, 0.65, 0.7, 0.75], 'g-^', linewidth=2, label='Robustness')
423        axes[0, 1].set_title('Performance Evolution')
424        axes[0, 1].set_xlabel('Time/Iteration')
425        axes[0, 1].set_ylabel('Normalized Score')
426        axes[0, 1].legend()
427        axes[0, 1].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
428        axes[0, 1].set_ylim(0, 1)
429
430        # Performance comparison bar chart
431        comparison_data = {
432            'Current': metrics_values[:-1],  # Remove duplicated last element
433            'Target': [0.9] * len(metrics_names),
434            'Baseline': [0.5] * len(metrics_names)
435        }
436
437        x = np.arange(len(metrics_names))
438        width = 0.25
439
440        for i, (label, values) in enumerate(comparison_data.items()):
441            offset = (i - 1) * width
442            bars = axes[1, 0].bar(x + offset, values, width, label=label, alpha=0.8)
443
444            # Add value labels on bars
445            for bar, value in zip(bars, values):
446                height = bar.get_height()
447                axes[1, 0].text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + 0.01,
448                               f'{value:.2f}', ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=9)
449
450        axes[1, 0].set_title('Performance Comparison')
451        axes[1, 0].set_xlabel('Metrics')
452        axes[1, 0].set_ylabel('Normalized Score')
453        axes[1, 0].set_xticks(x)
454        axes[1, 0].set_xticklabels(metrics_names, rotation=45, ha='right')
455        axes[1, 0].legend()
456        axes[1, 0].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
457        axes[1, 0].set_ylim(0, 1.1)
458
459        # Performance summary table
460        axes[1, 1].axis('off')
461
462        # Create summary statistics
463        if metrics_values:
464            overall_score = np.mean(metrics_values[:-1])  # Remove duplicated last element
465            min_score = np.min(metrics_values[:-1])
466            max_score = np.max(metrics_values[:-1])
467            std_score = np.std(metrics_values[:-1])
468        else:
469            overall_score = min_score = max_score = std_score = 0
470
471        summary_text = f"""Performance Summary
472
473Overall Score: {overall_score:.3f}
474Best Metric: {max_score:.3f}
475Worst Metric: {min_score:.3f}
476Std Deviation: {std_score:.3f}
477
478Performance Grade: {'A' if overall_score > 0.8 else 'B' if overall_score > 0.6 else 'C' if overall_score > 0.4 else 'D'}
479
480Recommendations:
481â€¢ {'Excellent performance' if overall_score > 0.8 else 'Good performance, minor improvements needed' if overall_score > 0.6 else 'Moderate performance, optimization required' if overall_score > 0.4 else 'Poor performance, major improvements needed'}
482â€¢ Focus on metrics with scores < 0.7
483â€¢ {'Maintain current tuning' if std_score < 0.1 else 'Balance metric performance'}"""
484
485        axes[1, 1].text(0.1, 0.9, summary_text, transform=axes[1, 1].transAxes,
486                       fontsize=11, verticalalignment='top', fontfamily='monospace',
487                       bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.5", facecolor="lightblue", alpha=0.8))
488
489        plt.tight_layout()
490
491        if save_path:
492            plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
493
494        return fig
495
496    def _estimate_settling_time(self, time: np.ndarray, signal: np.ndarray,
497                              tolerance: float = 0.02) -> Optional[float]:
498        """
499        Estimate settling time of a signal.
500
501        Args:
502            time: Time array
503            signal: Signal array
504            tolerance: Settling tolerance (2% by default)
505
506        Returns:
507            Estimated settling time or None if not found
508        """
509        if len(signal) < 10:
510            return None
511
512        final_value = signal[-100:].mean() if len(signal) >= 100 else signal[-10:].mean()
513
514        # Find the last time the signal exceeds the tolerance band
515        tolerance_band = abs(final_value) * tolerance
516
517        outside_band = abs(signal - final_value) > tolerance_band
518
519        if not np.any(outside_band):
520            return time[0]  # Already settled at start
521
522        # Find last index outside tolerance band
523        last_outside_idx = np.where(outside_band)[0][-1]
524
525        if last_outside_idx < len(time) - 1:
526            return time[last_outside_idx + 1]
527
528        return None  # Never settled within the simulation time

ClassesÂ¶

DiagnosticPlotterÂ¶

Specialized diagnostic plotting for control systems.

Source CodeÂ¶

  1class DiagnosticPlotter:
  2    """Specialized diagnostic plotting for control systems."""
  3
  4    def __init__(self, style: str = 'control_engineering', figsize: Tuple[int, int] = (12, 8)):
  5        """
  6        Initialize diagnostic plotter with control engineering styling.
  7
  8        Args:
  9            style: Plotting style for control engineering
 10            figsize: Default figure size
 11        """
 12        self.style = style
 13        self.figsize = figsize
 14        self._setup_style()
 15
 16    def _setup_style(self) -> None:
 17        """Configure matplotlib style for control engineering plots."""
 18        # Control engineering specific styling
 19        params = {
 20            'figure.figsize': self.figsize,
 21            'axes.labelsize': 12,
 22            'axes.titlesize': 14,
 23            'xtick.labelsize': 10,
 24            'ytick.labelsize': 10,
 25            'legend.fontsize': 10,
 26            'font.family': 'serif',
 27            'axes.grid': True,
 28            'grid.alpha': 0.3,
 29            'lines.linewidth': 1.5,
 30            'axes.axisbelow': True
 31        }
 32        plt.rcParams.update(params)
 33
 34    def plot_time_response(self,
 35                          simulation_data: SimulationData,
 36                          variables: Optional[List[str]] = None,
 37                          title: str = "System Time Response",
 38                          save_path: Optional[str] = None) -> plt.Figure:
 39        """
 40        Plot comprehensive time-domain response analysis.
 41
 42        Args:
 43            simulation_data: Simulation data containing time series
 44            variables: Specific variables to plot (None for all)
 45            title: Plot title
 46            save_path: Path to save the plot
 47
 48        Returns:
 49            matplotlib Figure object
 50        """
 51        time = simulation_data.time
 52        states = simulation_data.states
 53        control_inputs = simulation_data.control_inputs
 54
 55        if variables is None:
 56            # Determine key variables based on available data
 57            n_states = states.shape[1] if states is not None else 0
 58            n_inputs = control_inputs.shape[1] if control_inputs is not None else 0
 59            variables = []
 60
 61            if n_states >= 4:  # Assume double pendulum: [Î¸1, Î¸1_dot, Î¸2, Î¸2_dot]
 62                variables = ['Î¸â‚ (rad)', 'Î¸Ì‡â‚ (rad/s)', 'Î¸â‚‚ (rad)', 'Î¸Ì‡â‚‚ (rad/s)']
 63            elif n_states >= 2:
 64                variables = [f'x_{i+1}' for i in range(n_states)]
 65
 66        n_plots = len(variables) + (1 if control_inputs is not None else 0)
 67        n_cols = 2
 68        n_rows = (n_plots + n_cols - 1) // n_cols
 69
 70        fig, axes = plt.subplots(n_rows, n_cols, figsize=(15, 4*n_rows))
 71        if n_rows == 1:
 72            axes = [axes]
 73        if n_cols == 1 or n_rows == 1:
 74            axes = axes.flatten() if hasattr(axes, 'flatten') else [axes]
 75        else:
 76            axes = axes.flatten()
 77
 78        fig.suptitle(title, fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')
 79
 80        plot_idx = 0
 81
 82        # Plot state variables
 83        if states is not None:
 84            for i, var_name in enumerate(variables):
 85                if i >= states.shape[1]:
 86                    break
 87
 88                ax = axes[plot_idx]
 89                ax.plot(time, states[:, i], 'b-', linewidth=2, label=var_name)
 90
 91                # Add steady-state line if applicable
 92                final_value = states[-100:, i].mean()  # Average of last 100 points
 93                if abs(final_value) > 1e-6:
 94                    ax.axhline(y=final_value, color='r', linestyle='--', alpha=0.7,
 95                             label=f'Steady state: {final_value:.4f}')
 96
 97                # Highlight settling behavior
 98                settling_time = self._estimate_settling_time(time, states[:, i])
 99                if settling_time is not None:
100                    ax.axvline(x=settling_time, color='g', linestyle=':', alpha=0.7,
101                             label=f'Settling time: {settling_time:.2f}s')
102
103                ax.set_title(f'State Variable: {var_name}')
104                ax.set_xlabel('Time (s)')
105                ax.set_ylabel(var_name)
106                ax.legend()
107                ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
108
109                plot_idx += 1
110
111        # Plot control inputs
112        if control_inputs is not None and plot_idx < len(axes):
113            ax = axes[plot_idx]
114
115            if control_inputs.shape[1] == 1:
116                ax.plot(time, control_inputs[:, 0], 'r-', linewidth=2, label='Control Input')
117                ax.set_title('Control Input')
118                ax.set_ylabel('u(t)')
119            else:
120                for i in range(min(3, control_inputs.shape[1])):  # Limit to 3 inputs
121                    ax.plot(time, control_inputs[:, i], linewidth=2, label=f'u_{i+1}(t)')
122                ax.set_title('Control Inputs')
123                ax.set_ylabel('Control Signal')
124
125            ax.set_xlabel('Time (s)')
126            ax.legend()
127            ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
128
129            # Add control effort statistics
130            total_effort = np.sum(np.abs(control_inputs))
131            max_effort = np.max(np.abs(control_inputs))
132            ax.text(0.02, 0.98, f'Total effort: {total_effort:.2f}\nMax effort: {max_effort:.2f}',
133                   transform=ax.transAxes, verticalalignment='top',
134                   bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.3", facecolor="white", alpha=0.8))
135
136            plot_idx += 1
137
138        # Hide unused subplots
139        for idx in range(plot_idx, len(axes)):
140            axes[idx].axis('off')
141
142        plt.tight_layout()
143
144        if save_path:
145            plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
146
147        return fig
148
149    def plot_phase_portrait(self,
150                          simulation_data: SimulationData,
151                          state_pairs: Optional[List[Tuple[int, int]]] = None,
152                          title: str = "Phase Portrait Analysis",
153                          save_path: Optional[str] = None) -> plt.Figure:
154        """
155        Create phase portrait plots for nonlinear system analysis.
156
157        Args:
158            simulation_data: Simulation data containing state trajectories
159            state_pairs: Pairs of state indices to plot (None for default)
160            title: Plot title
161            save_path: Path to save the plot
162
163        Returns:
164            matplotlib Figure object
165        """
166        states = simulation_data.states
167
168        if state_pairs is None:
169            # Default pairs for double pendulum
170            if states.shape[1] >= 4:
171                state_pairs = [(0, 1), (2, 3)]  # (Î¸1, Î¸1_dot), (Î¸2, Î¸2_dot)
172            elif states.shape[1] >= 2:
173                state_pairs = [(0, 1)]
174            else:
175                raise ValueError("Need at least 2 states for phase portrait")
176
177        n_pairs = len(state_pairs)
178        n_cols = min(2, n_pairs)
179        n_rows = (n_pairs + n_cols - 1) // n_cols
180
181        fig, axes = plt.subplots(n_rows, n_cols, figsize=(6*n_cols, 6*n_rows))
182        if n_pairs == 1:
183            axes = [axes]
184        elif n_rows == 1:
185            axes = [axes]
186        else:
187            axes = axes.flatten()
188
189        fig.suptitle(title, fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')
190
191        for idx, (i, j) in enumerate(state_pairs):
192            if idx >= len(axes):
193                break
194
195            ax = axes[idx]
196
197            # Plot trajectory
198            ax.plot(states[:, i], states[:, j], 'b-', linewidth=2, alpha=0.8, label='Trajectory')
199
200            # Mark initial and final points
201            ax.plot(states[0, i], states[0, j], 'go', markersize=10, label='Initial')
202            ax.plot(states[-1, i], states[-1, j], 'ro', markersize=10, label='Final')
203
204            # Add direction arrows
205            n_arrows = 10
206            arrow_indices = np.linspace(0, len(states)-2, n_arrows, dtype=int)
207            for arrow_idx in arrow_indices:
208                dx = states[arrow_idx+1, i] - states[arrow_idx, i]
209                dy = states[arrow_idx+1, j] - states[arrow_idx, j]
210                if abs(dx) > 1e-8 or abs(dy) > 1e-8:  # Avoid zero-length arrows
211                    ax.arrow(states[arrow_idx, i], states[arrow_idx, j], dx*0.1, dy*0.1,
212                           head_width=0.02, head_length=0.02, fc='red', ec='red', alpha=0.6)
213
214            # Equilibrium points (assuming origin)
215            ax.plot(0, 0, 'k*', markersize=15, label='Equilibrium')
216
217            # Set labels based on state indices
218            if states.shape[1] >= 4:  # Double pendulum
219                labels = ['Î¸â‚ (rad)', 'Î¸Ì‡â‚ (rad/s)', 'Î¸â‚‚ (rad)', 'Î¸Ì‡â‚‚ (rad/s)']
220                ax.set_xlabel(labels[i] if i < len(labels) else f'State {i+1}')
221                ax.set_ylabel(labels[j] if j < len(labels) else f'State {j+1}')
222                ax.set_title(f'Phase Portrait: {labels[i]} vs {labels[j]}')
223            else:
224                ax.set_xlabel(f'State {i+1}')
225                ax.set_ylabel(f'State {j+1}')
226                ax.set_title(f'Phase Portrait: x_{i+1} vs x_{j+1}')
227
228            ax.legend()
229            ax.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
230            ax.axis('equal')
231
232        # Hide unused subplots
233        for idx in range(n_pairs, len(axes)):
234            axes[idx].axis('off')
235
236        plt.tight_layout()
237
238        if save_path:
239            plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
240
241        return fig
242
243    def plot_frequency_analysis(self,
244                              simulation_data: SimulationData,
245                              signal_indices: Optional[List[int]] = None,
246                              title: str = "Frequency Domain Analysis",
247                              save_path: Optional[str] = None) -> plt.Figure:
248        """
249        Perform frequency domain analysis of system signals.
250
251        Args:
252            simulation_data: Simulation data containing signals
253            signal_indices: Indices of signals to analyze (None for all states)
254            title: Plot title
255            save_path: Path to save the plot
256
257        Returns:
258            matplotlib Figure object
259        """
260        time = simulation_data.time
261        states = simulation_data.states
262        dt = time[1] - time[0] if len(time) > 1 else 0.01
263
264        if signal_indices is None:
265            signal_indices = list(range(min(4, states.shape[1])))  # Limit to first 4 signals
266
267        n_signals = len(signal_indices)
268
269        fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, n_signals, figsize=(5*n_signals, 10))
270        if n_signals == 1:
271            axes = axes.reshape(2, 1)
272
273        fig.suptitle(title, fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')
274
275        for idx, signal_idx in enumerate(signal_indices):
276            signal_data = states[:, signal_idx]
277
278            # Time domain plot
279            axes[0, idx].plot(time, signal_data, 'b-', linewidth=2)
280            axes[0, idx].set_title(f'Time Domain - Signal {signal_idx+1}')
281            axes[0, idx].set_xlabel('Time (s)')
282            axes[0, idx].set_ylabel('Amplitude')
283            axes[0, idx].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
284
285            # Frequency domain analysis
286            N = len(signal_data)
287            frequencies = fft.fftfreq(N, dt)[:N//2]
288            fft_signal = fft.fft(signal_data)
289            magnitude = np.abs(fft_signal)[:N//2]
290
291            # Plot magnitude spectrum
292            axes[1, idx].semilogx(frequencies[1:], 20*np.log10(magnitude[1:]), 'r-', linewidth=2)
293            axes[1, idx].set_title(f'Frequency Domain - Signal {signal_idx+1}')
294            axes[1, idx].set_xlabel('Frequency (Hz)')
295            axes[1, idx].set_ylabel('Magnitude (dB)')
296            axes[1, idx].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
297
298            # Find and mark dominant frequencies
299            dominant_freq_idx = np.argmax(magnitude[1:]) + 1  # Skip DC component
300            dominant_freq = frequencies[dominant_freq_idx]
301            dominant_mag = magnitude[dominant_freq_idx]
302
303            axes[1, idx].plot(dominant_freq, 20*np.log10(dominant_mag), 'go', markersize=8,
304                            label=f'Dominant: {dominant_freq:.2f} Hz')
305            axes[1, idx].legend()
306
307            # Add frequency statistics
308            # Find all peaks above certain threshold
309            threshold = np.max(magnitude) * 0.1  # 10% of max magnitude
310            peak_indices = signal.find_peaks(magnitude, height=threshold)[0]
311            peak_freqs = frequencies[peak_indices]
312
313            if len(peak_freqs) > 0:
314                stats_text = f"Dominant freq: {dominant_freq:.2f} Hz\n"
315                stats_text += f"Peak count: {len(peak_freqs)}\n"
316                stats_text += f"Bandwidth: {np.max(peak_freqs) - np.min(peak_freqs):.2f} Hz"
317
318                axes[1, idx].text(0.02, 0.98, stats_text, transform=axes[1, idx].transAxes,
319                                verticalalignment='top', fontsize=9,
320                                bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.3", facecolor="white", alpha=0.8))
321
322        plt.tight_layout()
323
324        if save_path:
325            plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
326
327        return fig
328
329    def plot_control_performance(self,
330                               performance_metrics: PerformanceMetrics,
331                               title: str = "Control Performance Analysis",
332                               save_path: Optional[str] = None) -> plt.Figure:
333        """
334        Visualize control performance metrics.
335
336        Args:
337            performance_metrics: Performance metrics data
338            title: Plot title
339            save_path: Path to save the plot
340
341        Returns:
342            matplotlib Figure object
343        """
344        fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(15, 12))
345        fig.suptitle(title, fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')
346
347        # Performance metrics radar chart
348        metrics_names = []
349        metrics_values = []
350
351        # Extract available metrics
352        if hasattr(performance_metrics, 'settling_time') and performance_metrics.settling_time is not None:
353            metrics_names.append('Settling Time')
354            # Normalize settling time (lower is better, so invert)
355            normalized_settling = max(0, 1 - performance_metrics.settling_time / 10.0)
356            metrics_values.append(normalized_settling)
357
358        if hasattr(performance_metrics, 'overshoot') and performance_metrics.overshoot is not None:
359            metrics_names.append('Overshoot')
360            # Normalize overshoot (lower is better, so invert)
361            normalized_overshoot = max(0, 1 - performance_metrics.overshoot / 100.0)
362            metrics_values.append(normalized_overshoot)
363
364        if hasattr(performance_metrics, 'steady_state_error') and performance_metrics.steady_state_error is not None:
365            metrics_names.append('Steady State Error')
366            # Normalize error (lower is better, so invert)
367            normalized_error = max(0, 1 - abs(performance_metrics.steady_state_error))
368            metrics_values.append(normalized_error)
369
370        if hasattr(performance_metrics, 'control_effort') and performance_metrics.control_effort is not None:
371            metrics_names.append('Control Effort')
372            # Normalize control effort (lower is better, so invert)
373            normalized_effort = max(0, 1 - performance_metrics.control_effort / 1000.0)
374            metrics_values.append(normalized_effort)
375
376        # Add default metrics if none available
377        if not metrics_names:
378            metrics_names = ['Stability', 'Performance', 'Robustness', 'Efficiency']
379            metrics_values = [0.8, 0.7, 0.6, 0.9]  # Example values
380
381        # Create radar chart
382        angles = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, len(metrics_names), endpoint=False).tolist()
383        metrics_values += metrics_values[:1]  # Close the plot
384        angles += angles[:1]
385
386        ax_radar = plt.subplot(2, 2, 1, projection='polar')
387        ax_radar.plot(angles, metrics_values, 'bo-', linewidth=2, markersize=8)
388        ax_radar.fill(angles, metrics_values, alpha=0.25)
389        ax_radar.set_xticks(angles[:-1])
390        ax_radar.set_xticklabels(metrics_names)
391        ax_radar.set_ylim(0, 1)
392        ax_radar.set_title('Performance Radar Chart', pad=20)
393        ax_radar.grid(True)
394
395        # Performance trends (if time series data available)
396        # This would show how metrics evolve over time
397        axes[0, 1].plot([0, 1, 2, 3, 4], [0.5, 0.7, 0.8, 0.85, 0.9], 'b-o', linewidth=2, label='Stability')
398        axes[0, 1].plot([0, 1, 2, 3, 4], [0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.75, 0.8], 'r-s', linewidth=2, label='Performance')
399        axes[0, 1].plot([0, 1, 2, 3, 4], [0.4, 0.6, 0.65, 0.7, 0.75], 'g-^', linewidth=2, label='Robustness')
400        axes[0, 1].set_title('Performance Evolution')
401        axes[0, 1].set_xlabel('Time/Iteration')
402        axes[0, 1].set_ylabel('Normalized Score')
403        axes[0, 1].legend()
404        axes[0, 1].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
405        axes[0, 1].set_ylim(0, 1)
406
407        # Performance comparison bar chart
408        comparison_data = {
409            'Current': metrics_values[:-1],  # Remove duplicated last element
410            'Target': [0.9] * len(metrics_names),
411            'Baseline': [0.5] * len(metrics_names)
412        }
413
414        x = np.arange(len(metrics_names))
415        width = 0.25
416
417        for i, (label, values) in enumerate(comparison_data.items()):
418            offset = (i - 1) * width
419            bars = axes[1, 0].bar(x + offset, values, width, label=label, alpha=0.8)
420
421            # Add value labels on bars
422            for bar, value in zip(bars, values):
423                height = bar.get_height()
424                axes[1, 0].text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + 0.01,
425                               f'{value:.2f}', ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=9)
426
427        axes[1, 0].set_title('Performance Comparison')
428        axes[1, 0].set_xlabel('Metrics')
429        axes[1, 0].set_ylabel('Normalized Score')
430        axes[1, 0].set_xticks(x)
431        axes[1, 0].set_xticklabels(metrics_names, rotation=45, ha='right')
432        axes[1, 0].legend()
433        axes[1, 0].grid(True, alpha=0.3)
434        axes[1, 0].set_ylim(0, 1.1)
435
436        # Performance summary table
437        axes[1, 1].axis('off')
438
439        # Create summary statistics
440        if metrics_values:
441            overall_score = np.mean(metrics_values[:-1])  # Remove duplicated last element
442            min_score = np.min(metrics_values[:-1])
443            max_score = np.max(metrics_values[:-1])
444            std_score = np.std(metrics_values[:-1])
445        else:
446            overall_score = min_score = max_score = std_score = 0
447
448        summary_text = f"""Performance Summary
449
450Overall Score: {overall_score:.3f}
451Best Metric: {max_score:.3f}
452Worst Metric: {min_score:.3f}
453Std Deviation: {std_score:.3f}
454
455Performance Grade: {'A' if overall_score > 0.8 else 'B' if overall_score > 0.6 else 'C' if overall_score > 0.4 else 'D'}
456
457Recommendations:
458â€¢ {'Excellent performance' if overall_score > 0.8 else 'Good performance, minor improvements needed' if overall_score > 0.6 else 'Moderate performance, optimization required' if overall_score > 0.4 else 'Poor performance, major improvements needed'}
459â€¢ Focus on metrics with scores < 0.7
460â€¢ {'Maintain current tuning' if std_score < 0.1 else 'Balance metric performance'}"""
461
462        axes[1, 1].text(0.1, 0.9, summary_text, transform=axes[1, 1].transAxes,
463                       fontsize=11, verticalalignment='top', fontfamily='monospace',
464                       bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.5", facecolor="lightblue", alpha=0.8))
465
466        plt.tight_layout()
467
468        if save_path:
469            plt.savefig(save_path, dpi=300, bbox_inches='tight')
470
471        return fig
472
473    def _estimate_settling_time(self, time: np.ndarray, signal: np.ndarray,
474                              tolerance: float = 0.02) -> Optional[float]:
475        """
476        Estimate settling time of a signal.
477
478        Args:
479            time: Time array
480            signal: Signal array
481            tolerance: Settling tolerance (2% by default)
482
483        Returns:
484            Estimated settling time or None if not found
485        """
486        if len(signal) < 10:
487            return None
488
489        final_value = signal[-100:].mean() if len(signal) >= 100 else signal[-10:].mean()
490
491        # Find the last time the signal exceeds the tolerance band
492        tolerance_band = abs(final_value) * tolerance
493
494        outside_band = abs(signal - final_value) > tolerance_band
495
496        if not np.any(outside_band):
497            return time[0]  # Already settled at start
498
499        # Find last index outside tolerance band
500        last_outside_idx = np.where(outside_band)[0][-1]
501
502        if last_outside_idx < len(time) - 1:
503            return time[last_outside_idx + 1]
504
505        return None  # Never settled within the simulation time
